spelling stands for the /o/ sound as in boat. Point to the spelling, say the letter names and sound, and have students repeat. Continue with the following spellings and words:

Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having students repeat, then reblending the word together.

Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of The Kind Crows.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Personal Response
Have students write about the lesson they learned from this story and how they could use the lesson in their own lives.
Allow students to orally share with a partner what they want to write before writing.
Prompt them to look back at the story for support in writing.
Students can complete the writing during independent work time.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that the picture shows crows, which are a type of bird. Have students find the crows in the picture.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to be willing to share.
with her money and gives it away to charities.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what the shiny yellow bead was made of. (gold)
What does Kenzo do that shows he is generous? Find sentences that answer the question.
Could this story happen in real life? Why or why not?
How have you been generous with someone who needed help? What did you do?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

Ask students to say each pictures name. Guide students in reading the sentence on the back of the card. Offer support.
Then guide them to build the word with Letter Cards. They can self-correct using the word on the back of the card.

Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Mountain Goats.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a List
Have students list three to five facts they learned about mountain goats.
Have them draw a picture to accompany their list.
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that a mountain goat is a special kind of goat that lives high up in the mountains where few other animals can live.

When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that describes the weather in the mountains. (cold)
What body parts have helped the mountain goat adapt to living in the mountains? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why are the mountains a good home for the mountain goat?
What is one thing you think is most interesting about the mountain goat? Why do you think so?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

A rowboat is a boat that you row.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during wordbuilding exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
/ square. Add a square to show me
Students should add a different color square after the purple /
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /
Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Who Knows?
Dictate the following sentences for students to write, one at a time:
Dad will load the stones on the truck. Which box will hold the most?
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. A riddle is a tricky word puzzle that you use clues to solve.

For the first reading, have students read the riddle while you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the riddles. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingone reads the riddle while the other supplies the answer.
Prompt students to find all the words with long
spellings in the riddles and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of each students errors on their Student Observation Form.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the number of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

PD Expert Video: Reading Decodable Text
Draw a ladder on the board.
Have students work together to write each word on a ladder rung.
Model how to look for smaller words in the following compound words in order to read them:
. Guide students to read each word and discuss its meaning based on the two smaller words.
Have students add smaller words to the following words to see how many words they can make:
. List the words as they form them. Discuss their meanings.
Have students select two of the words from the list and write sentences for them.
This is something cars drive on.
to name a kind of insect.
to name a way to cook things.
to name bread that has been browned.
to name a kind of animal.
to make a word that is the past form of
Read, Build, Write: here, look, me, play, said, see, she, try, about, because
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
Have students whisper-read King Midas from Lesson 9 to build fluency.
Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable
. Ask students to repeat and blend the syllables into a word:
. Ask students to repeat and segment the word into the syllables they hear:
Tell me the two syllables you hear in snowman. Put your hand under your chin. Each chin drop is a syllable.
Circulate, listen in, and provide corrective feedback.
Note high-frequency words and phonics skills for which students need additional support.
Include and highlight these words in activities throughout the upcoming lessons.
Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Assess students using this units Cumulative Assessment for accuracy and fluency on phonics skills. Take note of fluency issues and decayed learning.
Dictate the following words and sentences:
My coach hopes I can make a goal.
It is cold, and it may snow here.

Use the Cumulative Assessments for Decoding, High-Frequency Words, and Dictation to determine student progress toward mastering the focus skill for this unit and the previous few units. In addition, review your observations of student reading and writing for evidence of skill mastery. Use this information to determine which skills need increased focus and for which students in upcoming lessons.
